SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and occasional bloating. He attributes these symptoms to recent home renovations and a change in diet due to the construction of his kitchen. The patient has been experiencing these symptoms for about five weeks. He denies fever, chills, and significant shortness of breath, but reports slight chest cramps that resolve within an hour and a mild cough. The patient has been monitoring his blood pressure at home and reports that it has been well-controlled.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No fevers, chills. Positive fatigue and lightheadedness.
• Cardiovascular: Slight chest cramps. No significant shortness of breath.
• Respiratory: Mild cough. No significant shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Occasional bloating. No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Vital signs within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 cm.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Reduced pumping function at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Monitor daily weight and report any significant weight gain or worsening shortness of breath. Order a follow-up echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure is well-controlled at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevated readings through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She reports that she was changing a light bulb on a ladder yesterday and had a stumble, twisting her knee as she tried to catch her fall. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial portion of the knee, over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited with flexion and valgus stress. Normal sensation in the lower extremity. No calf pain.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the left knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present, but overall alignment appears normal.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus sprain or strain of the right knee.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide her with crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food, for a two-week supply. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning, and he felt a pop in his lower back. He had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved, but it has been stiff ever since. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat without significant relief. He experienced tingling in his toes on his right foot until Sunday afternoon.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Denies chest pain.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in toes on the right foot.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation at the lumbar spine. Decreased range of motion with flexion and extension. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

X-ray lumbar spine, ordered and obtained in the office today, is unremarkable with good bony alignment.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing and avoid strenuous activity.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy for further evaluation and treatment.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: He has been compliant with metformin and dietary modifications, but his recent hemoglobin A1c was 8.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are slightly elevated, and better control is needed.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his knee osteoarthritis well and no further workup is needed at this time.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current management.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam.

Regarding his depression, he has been taking Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He has been managing his hypertension with Norvasc, but admits to occasionally forgetting to take it on weekends. He had a lobectomy a couple of years ago and has experienced some shortness of breath during exercise, particularly in humid conditions.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pounding during exercise.
• Respiratory: Shortness of breath with exertion.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is doing well on Prozac 20 mg daily.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Refill prescription for Prozac.

2. Prior Lobectomy:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is exercising regularly and has good breathing function.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon needed.

3. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-controlled on Norvasc.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue current medication regimen.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident over the weekend. She reports that her finger was bent backward while skiing over moguls.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation
Appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger obtained on today's visit show no fractures.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for a week. If the pain does not improve, the patient is advised to call and return for a follow-up. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia, who presents today for further evaluation. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. The patient reports fatigue, feverishness, chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She has been anemic since the age of 13 and had a hysterectomy in 1996. She had a colonoscopy approximately 5-6 years ago with no significant findings. The patient denies having a pacemaker, defibrillator, sleep apnea, or using oxygen at night. She drinks alcohol only once or twice a year. She is currently taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Endorses fatigue, feverishness, and chills.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath and wheezing.
• Neurological: Endorses headaches.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Patient is alert and oriented.
• Cardiovascular: Normal heart sounds.
• Respiratory: Normal breath sounds.
• Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, and non-distended.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia, presenting for further evaluation.

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been dealing with anemia for a long time, with recent blood work showing low hemoglobin, stable hematocrit, normal iron labs, and low ferritin. She is currently taking ferrous sulfate and vitamin B12.
• Additional Testing: We will schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If these tests are inconclusive, a capsule endoscopy will be considered. We will recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 12 weeks.
• Specialist Referrals: A referral has been sent to a hematologist for further evaluation and management.
• Patient Education and Counseling: The patient is advised to continue taking ferrous sulfate with orange juice (for vitamin C) to improve iron absorption. She will follow up with the hematologist and undergo the recommended endoscopic procedures.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male, who presents to the clinic today for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. The patient was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward initially presented to his primary care provider on 3/1/21 with complaints of worsening headaches over the past few months. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for worsening headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Pertinent labs and radiology studies were reviewed, including a pituitary hormone profile demonstrating a low TSH, and an MRI revealing a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm.

The patient reports headaches located behind his eyes, with a dull nagging ache. The onset was gradual, starting about three months ago and worsening over time. The headaches tend to be worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. The patient denies any other symptoms, such as feeling sick, fever, rashes, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. However, he has noticed recently bumping into door frames.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
None.

Family
Adopted, family history unknown.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Occupation: Computer programmer.
Marital status: Married for 25 years.
Alcohol, smoking, and recreational drug use: None.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

The patient is alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

ASSESSMENT

Pituitary adenoma with optic chiasmal compression.

PLAN

1. Recommend surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa.
2. Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to map peripheral vision prior to surgery.
3. Schedule surgery through the surgery scheduler, Deborah.
4. Monitor patient's vision post-surgery for improvement.

The patient is informed of the risks associated with anesthesia and surgery, including infection, need for further surgery, wound issues, seizure, stroke, permanent numbness, weakness, difficulty speaking, or even death. The patient understands the risks and agrees to proceed with the surgery.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal. She presents as a new patient with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. She reports having chest pain for four days in early October 2020, which resolved on its own. The patient denies any recent episodes of chest pain since then. She experienced difficulty swallowing during the initial episode, which has also resolved. The patient reports mild tenderness in the upper abdominal quadrants during the physical examination. She was going through a stressful job transition at the time of the chest pain.

ER records indicate normal cardiac workup, including EKG and blood tests.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Abdominal
• Examination of Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No pain or tenderness in the lower belly.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal. She presents with a referral for esophagitis following an episode of chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020. Cardiac issues were ruled out in the ER. Possible etiologies include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, and anxiety. The patient's job transition stress may have contributed to her symptoms.

The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change. An EGD was discussed but deferred due to the patient being asymptomatic for an extended period. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of kidney function in a patient with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, who presents today for evaluation of kidney function. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation. She has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will be starting speech therapy soon. She has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. The geneticist mentioned the possibility of kidney anomalies in patients with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

The patient's mother reports that Katherine has 8-10 wet diapers per day and drinks an adequate amount of fluids, including water and non-dairy milk. Katherine's twin sister is doing well and has no health issues.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: No issues reported.
• Cardiovascular: No issues reported.
• Respiratory: No issues reported.
• Gastrointestinal: History of reflux and feeding difficulties.
• Genitourinary: Adequate urine output, 8-10 wet diapers per day.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Neurological: Developmental delays, history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Unremarkable.
• Cardiovascular: Normal heart sounds.
• Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Gastrointestinal: Soft, non-tender, non-distended.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Neurological: Alert and oriented, developmental delays.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of kidney function. Given the potential for congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract in patients with Smith-Magenis Syndrome, we will obtain a kidney ultrasound today for screening purposes.

• Kidney Ultrasound: If the ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up will be needed. If there are abnormalities, we will determine the next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location.

Patient Agreements: The patient's mother understands and agrees with the recommended medical evaluation plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her outstretched arms. The patient reports severe pain, rated as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The injury occurred yesterday morning.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Reports some tingling in fingers, but no numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20
Temp: 97.2°F
SPO2: Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: No carotid bruit, no murmur, rub, or gallop.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: Palpable pulses, no lower edema.
MSK: Right wrist with obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation throughout. Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Able to make a fist but not tightly. Bony crepitus noted.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a positive Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. I have recommended conservative treatment initially with a wrist brace. The patient will be scheduled for surgery as soon as possible. Post-surgery, the patient will be placed in a brace for six weeks and will attend physical therapy three times per week. The patient will be prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled in one month to assess the patient's progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to follow the prescribed treatment plan and attend all scheduled appointments. If her pain does not improve or worsens, she will contact the office for further evaluation.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, managed with 20 mg of Lisinopril.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: Not provided
Respiration: Not provided
No fever.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur. No other abnormalities.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Pain with flexion and extension. Pain to palpation of the medial aspect. Edema around the knee and effusion present. No pain on the lateral aspect.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed. No fractures or bony abnormalities were found.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient reports slipping and falling, causing knee pain and swelling.
- Medical Treatment: Ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Knee brace for support. Ice therapy 20 minutes, 3-4 times daily for swelling.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Advised to elevate leg and stay off the leg for a couple of weeks.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of hypertension and is currently on Lisinopril 20 mg.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg. Referral to nutrition for dietary management.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the importance of diet in managing hypertension and the goal of eventually reducing or eliminating the need for medication.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and putting in a new ceiling. The patient states he is very active and has experienced left shoulder pain before that usually resolves with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain and instability. The patient reports that her left knee occasionally gives out while walking, causing her to nearly fall. She describes the pain as internal and involving the whole kneecap. The pain comes and goes quickly, and she has not taken any medications for it. The patient denies any history of injury to the left knee and has not heard or felt a pop. She is concerned about her upcoming trip, which will involve a lot of walking and line dancing, and is considering not participating in the dancing due to her knee issues.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability. Denies right knee pain.

Cardiovascular: Reports taking blood pressure medications regularly.

Endocrine: Reports taking metformin for diabetes management.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.

Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

MSK: Examination of the left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation of the left medial knee. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain and instability, likely due to arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. For the left knee pain and instability, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider initiating physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee.
2. Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order a hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and potential adjustments to metformin dosage.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough and sore throat.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She is currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. Biopsy of a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports good support from nursing staff, family, and friends.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports a dry cough and sore throat. Denies shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea or vomiting. Reports decreased appetite.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Neck
- Examination: No cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination: Erythema on the anterior side of the chest on the left side, possibly related to radiation.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide and radiation therapy.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with the current chemotherapy regimen and radiation therapy. Repeat imaging after completion of radiation therapy to assess tumor response and potential for surgical resection.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's cough and crackles on lung exam are likely due to radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation.

3. Sore throat and painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's sore throat is likely due to inflammation in the esophagus from radiation therapy.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low immunoglobulin A level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient was referred by their primary care physician due to abnormal lab work showing a low immunoglobulin A level. Patient reports frequent colds in the wintertime that tend to linger but is unsure if this is more than usual.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Type 2 diabetes, recently started on metformin.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient works in a family-owned donut shop.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Gastrointestinal: No abdominal pain or diarrhea.

VITALS

Vitals were reviewed and within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LABS

Immunoglobulin A level was found to be low.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low immunoglobulin A level.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work is consistent with an IgA deficiency, which is a common immunodeficiency. Patient does not report significant infections or symptoms that would warrant immediate concern.
- Additional Testing: Order blood work to check for other antibody levels to rule out other immunodeficiencies.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the nature of IgA deficiency and advised the patient to monitor for any changes in infections or abdominal symptoms. Instructed the patient to inform medical professionals of their IgA deficiency if they require blood products in the future.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended assessment and plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately 4 days. The pain is localized to the medial aspect of his elbow and can radiate down into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow. The pain is rated as a 6/10 and has been affecting his sleep and daily activities. He has tried ibuprofen with minimal relief.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has recently been engaging in pottery and ceramics during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Pulses are equal in all extremities.
NEURO: Sensation is normal to light touch distally.
MSK: 
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. No pain with supination. Pain with pronation. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony misalignment.

ASSESSMENT

Medial epicondylitis of the right elbow.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the following plan:

1. Rest the right elbow and wear a sling while awake.
2. Apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day.
3. Take ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for a full week.
4. Hold off on pottery work for the next couple of weeks.
5. Follow-up appointment in one week to evaluate progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up after a fall and chest pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension and recent dietary indiscretion.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily, but admits to occasional missed doses.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pain, thought to be heartburn.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during exertion.
Genitourinary: No issues reported.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: Likely caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting sodium intake. Advised to monitor weight daily and contact the doctor if a 3-pound weight gain occurs in 2 days.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed dietary modifications and importance of medication adherence.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and groin. The pain is intermittent and comes with difficulty finding a comfortable position. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for pain with minimal relief. He feels nauseated but has not vomited. The patient has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones in his father.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports right-sided abdominal pain and nausea.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA: Positive tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and stone passage.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. Continue Tylenol as needed.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to strain urine and collect the stone when it passes.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1 to 2 weeks. If symptoms persist, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to contact the doctor if symptoms worsen or do not improve within the next week.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a male patient who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for approximately 6 weeks, which he first noticed after wearing tight shoes and going on a hike. The patient describes the ulcer as having a foul smell, yellow drainage, and blackened edges. He has been on antibiotics for 6 days and has experienced some improvement, but also reports calf cramping and a red streak along his calf muscle. The patient is diabetic with a history of well-controlled blood sugars, but has noticed a recent increase in blood sugar levels.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently tried new trails behind the park.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever of 99.7 and chills prior to starting antibiotics.
Cardiovascular: Reports cramping in calf muscle.
Respiratory: Reports recent coughing and difficulty catching breath.
Skin: Patient reports non-healing right foot ulcer with foul smell and yellow drainage.
Neurological: Patient reports well-controlled diabetic neuropathy.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure: Not provided
Heart rate: Not provided

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Not provided
RESPIRATORY: Not provided
NECK: Not provided
MSK: Examination of the right foot reveals a 2 x 2 cm necrotic wound on the heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler. No pain upon pressing the affected area.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer, right foot
2. Diabetes
3. Possible cellulitis

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination findings today, I have discussed the current symptoms and plan with the patient. We will order a test to check blood supply for the wound. A debridement will be performed in the office today, and a culture will be taken to assess the need for different antibiotic therapy. The patient will continue the current antibiotic course and follow up in 7 days. The patient is advised to follow up with their endocrinologist to ensure continued control of their diabetes and blood sugars.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee with associated pain and erythema.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports spending time outdoors and recently went hunting. He noticed a tick bite on his right knee over a week ago, which has been causing burning pain and discomfort. He denies fever, chills, joint pain in other areas, or difficulty moving the knee. He has not been previously diagnosed with Lyme disease.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension: Controlled with lisinopril 20 mg daily.
Diabetes: Controlled with metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or body aches. Reports headache and general malaise since tick bite.
Respiratory: Denies cough or shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Denies joint pain other than typical arthritic pain.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Respiration: Normal
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Full range of motion in right knee. Pain to palpation of right anterior knee.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Suspected Lyme disease due to tick bite and bull's-eye rash.
- Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm diagnosis.

2. Hypertension: Well-controlled on lisinopril 20 mg daily.
- Continue current medication.
- Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes: Blood sugars in the 120s, controlled with metformin 1000 mg twice daily.
- Continue current medication.
- Order hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control.
- Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.
